story:
Friends--

2015 has been an incredible year for my writing, and the positives just keep adding up: I have finished a first draft of my novel, presented at the 2015 AWP conference in Minneapolis on writing as a second career, been accepted as a resident at the Vermont Studio Center, and now have been accepted as a Kimbilio Fellow (http://kimbiliofiction.com/).

...Which brings me here. The great folks over at Kimbilio, whose mission includes providing crucial support for the projects of, and building a community around African American fiction writers, have offered to cover the cost of tuition for their weeklong summer writers retreat in Taos, New Mexico; however, room, board and travel are not covered. Attending the retreat would allow me to receive crucial feedback on my novel-in-progress from published authors whose work I admire. 

I have invested significantly in pursuing my own dream to become a published author, or I would not be here. Your contribution would help fund ground transportation by bus and shuttle to and from Taos, as well as the $600 room and board fee. A security deposit of $200 is due to Kimbilio by May 1st. If you are so inclined, please help me get to Kimbilio!

Thanks,

Talisha
story_txt: Friends--2015 has been an incredible year for my writing, and the positives just keep adding up: I have finished a first draft of my novel, presented at the 2015 AWP conference in Minneapolis on writing as a second career, been accepted as a resident at the Vermont Studio Center, and now have been accepted as a Kimbilio Fellow (http://kimbiliofiction.com/)....Which brings me here. The great folks over at Kimbilio, whose mission includes providing crucial support for the projects of, and building a community around African American fiction writers, have offered to cover the cost of tuition for their weeklong summer writers retreat in Taos, New Mexico; however, room, board and travel are not covered. Attending the retreat would allow me to receive crucial feedback on my novel-in-progress from published authors whose work I admire. I have invested significantly in pursuing my own dream to become a published author, or I would not be here. Your contribution would help fund ground transportation by bus and shuttle to and from Taos, as well as the $600 room and board fee. A security deposit of $200 is due to Kimbilio by May 1st. If you are so inclined, please help me get to Kimbilio!Thanks,Talisha

story:
Summary

2063: Project Weedpatch is a novel about the future of nonviolent change in the United States between now and the 100th anniversary of Martin Luther King's March on Washington. It's a sexy, diverse, grassroots campaign story that readers have said feels like a West Wing season or an HBO series. I wrote it in 2013 and 2014 during a somewhat ridiculous series of exploding startups and layoffs. My career chaos means fun stuff to read for you! The feedback from my early readers has been overwhelmingly positive; honestly it's been beyond the wildest expectations I had when I started out on this project. So I'm starting this pre-ordering campaign to get a good solid edit, a little dough for marketing, and a first print-on-demand run.

The good news is, the book is done. It's a little over 98,000 words. (novels usually run 80k to 100k words) eBook conversion isn't that tricky, so I've got a couple files sitting here on my machine with the whole book that I could upload to Amazon.

But. I haven't done that, for a good reason: I want this book to be as awesome as possible.

That means giving it a good solid round of professional editing. While I'm going to keep the marketing pretty minimal, I'll need a little dough in the piggybank to get it started. And I would like to do a small (for now) print-on-demand run, so readers who prefer ink and paper to eBooks can enjoy it too.

If you're curious from all this but still not sure, you can download the first chapter for free!

What You Get

I'm keeping the perks pretty simple. At the low end, you get ebooks, and since you're signing on early, you'll get them two weeks before I release them for sale to the general public. In the middle range, you'll get print copies from the small print-on-demand run that I'm planning on doing. (if you're not an eBook type and want a print version but don't want to pay a bit more, you'll have to be patient - it will be available in print at some point, I just can't yet say when.)

At the high end, I'll include your name on a special page of patrons. And at the very high end, I'm particularly excited about the $1000 perk: I'm going to throw a no-holds-barred fancypants dinner for the ten of you first to grab that. If you're willing to put up that kind of dough for this project, I can guarantee you're someone interesting! And it will be fun to introduce you all to each other.

New Perk: Hardcover with Merchandise!

Just added: a new perk that's the eBook two weeks before the masses, the hardcover copy when it's done - and a t-shirt, mug and fancy sticker! It's only a little more than the hardcover, too! There's only 25 of these since fulfilling them will be a pain in the keister! So snap them up now...


So Here's The Plan

This campaign is going to run for 30 days. Even though the book is written, editing is going to take a bit more time, so I'm breaking the release of it up into four parts. Besides making the process a little more manageable, this will a) get an ebook with the first part of the story in your hands as quickly as humanly possible (well before the election) and b) allow for getting more ideas from you smartypants readers about what's going to happen and where the story is going. I've already had SO many interesting conversations, I can't wait to have a whole bunch more. I will release each part as it's edited, every month or two. So the final version of the whole book and the printed hardcover versions, will most likely not be available until early 2017.

The Schedule

Here's the planned schedule. It's rough. It may change. It might be slower than this, but it's possible things might go faster too. Most likely I will take about a month and a half to edit the 6 to 8 chapters in parts one through four. The plan isn't to do a print run until all 4 parts are out, which should be early 2017. (ish) And keep in mind everyone who signs up here will get their copies two weeks before the general release:

July 2016 - edit then ship eBook of Part 1
September 2016 - ship eBook of Part 2
November 2016 - ship eBook of Part 3
January 2017 - ship Part 4 and hardcover copies (parts 1-4) 

Why Don't I Just Get A Publisher?

This is a really interesting question, and a proper answer would be longer than I have space for here. Summarizing greatly: getting a publisher is very difficult and time consuming, they can't move quickly enough and the amount of value they'd add at this stage is debatable. In my research I discovered that agents receive upwards of 5000 pitches per year and will take on 2-3 authors at the most. I like my odds with you all here a lot better!

None of this is to say that I'm not open to working with a traditional publisher at any point in this process. If you're interesting in reading more about this, I strongly recommend following Hugh Howey. In addition to being a kickass author, he's writing some of the the most intelligent stuff about the changes (and amazing digital renaissance) of the book industry. http://www.hughhowey.com/

The Impact

I need to be a little careful here, because if I'm totally honest with myself, I feel like the impact (and market) of this book could be...

truly...

YUUUGE!

It's a good book about a very timely topic that a LOT of people are thinking about right now. It's not hard to imagine half of anyone who has ever been involved in a presidential campaign wanting to read this. With a combination of your help, a little marketing and a little luck, we have a shot at reaching them. That's millions of people, and that's just in the US.

But, that may not happen. Maybe only a few thousand folks are going to read it. If so, OK. A few thousand people thinking about the future they really want to see for this country could be a very good thing. I'll be happy with that. I really will. But people smarter than me have suggested this could be a book that a lot of people read, and I agree. If so, think about how good you'll feel having been there at the beginning. (not to mention owning a very first edition!)

Risks & Challenges

Compared to a lot of crowdfunding campaigns, the risks here are pretty minimal since the thing is already written. Probably the biggest risk is that you're going to get annoyed with me not shipping each part quickly enough! To mitigate this risk, all backers hereby have permission to contact me at any time requesting and/or demanding that I hurry up with the next part. (I actually love messages like that!)

Other Ways You Can Help: Organize

Share it, share it and share it. I can't thank you enough for doing this. I don't want to spend a ton of money on marketing regardless of how this campaign does. You're my organizers.

Warning!

The book has a couple of slightly edgy, fairly graphic sex scenes. Some of the characters are LGBTQ, and some are in honest but nonmonogamous relationships. If this sort of thing makes you uncomfortable, this might not be the best read for you.

story:
Hi, I'm Ro. I'm writing a novella.

I'm 24 years old and I've been writing for 20 of them. You can check out my most recent work on my blog.
 
My passion for writing about the world around me led me to write a novella which I intend to self-publish on Amazon. The novella is titled Descending the Corporate Ladder. The writing is mostly complete, and it's now time to edit, design a cover, and publish -- that's where I could use a little help from you. 
 

Help me help others write.

As I prepare to self-publish, I need $2500 for final editing, designing a cover, and printing a few physical copies of my book. I'll pay it forward by donating up to $2500 to the SF WritersCorps, an organization dedicated to raising literacy in the Bay Area. Funds after $5000 will go towards additional printing and editing for my book. 

You Get

  • A book 
  • The SWEET perk for which you qualify
  • Warm and fuzzies of helping two people (me and an underprivileged kid or young-adult) achieve their writing dreams

You Give

  • Improved literacy and creative writing skills to SF youth
  • A means for this author to launch her novella into the world


What's the book about?

The power of keen determination, the reminder that life can be simultaneously trivial and heavy, and above all, the importance of recognizing your passions. The story follows a colorful free-spirited young professional who, increasingly disillusioned with the world around her and in desperate need of self-validation, decides to write a book. With the help of her cancer-diagnosed writing mentor, she discovers herself by writing about her own experiences with school, work, relationships, family, racism, and gender discrimination.

A candidly introspective, wise, and witty narrative about what it means to be a young twenty-something as it's experienced: the search for a niche, companion, and purpose in life. 

What are early readers saying?

"A timely lesson for our generation, Descending the Corporate Ladder perfectly encapsulates what it means to shave our creative instincts in order to fit the corporate mold and what it takes revisit our innermost ambitions. Highly recommend."

"[Rohini's] ability to reflect upon the confusion of being a 20 some year old today with a little bit of wit brings a sense relief to me. What I liked the most about the novella was that the author's self-reflection provided a forum for me to think through my experiences while reading."


A sneak peek (it's Chapter 6).

     Sunday morning came before I knew it. I awoke out of breath. Snap out of it. They accepted you for a reason. This is embarrassing. After an abridged morning routine I walked to the Wilde House, a Victorian building with fifty regal steps leading up to the front door.
     I climbed up the stairs. Five…ten…You can do this…Fifteen…What am I doing here? I should turn around…Fourteen…You’re being a child. Do you want to write a book or not?...Fifteen. I finally made it to the top where the gatekeeper, a mustachioed man wearing a tweed jacket, greeted me at the door. Before he could ask, I spat out the passcode. I was out of place (and not just because I was still standing outside). 
     The gatekeeper nodded and opened the door. Another man, who could have been his identical twin, was waiting on the other side of the door. The men exchanged glances, as if communicating telepathically. The second man stared at me to follow him. Not hearing a single word being spoken, I wondered if people at the Writers Guild relied solely on written communication. I followed him as he took me through a maze of tables. He came to a stop in front of a long rectangular mahogany table. Unprepared to stop so suddenly, I walked into him then hopped backwards. I looked like a klutz.
     Comfortably seated in front of us was an elderly man who could have been my grandfather, dressed in a long sleeve turtleneck, jeans, and sneakers. Sunken cheeks balanced his youthful eyes. His head was almost as shiny as the silver shell of his MacBook. The gatekeeper joined us inside. The first words were spoken. 
     “This is your new protégé, Sabena.” His handlebar mustache twitched as he spoke. “Well, I’ll leave you to it,” he said as he turned and glided away.
     Left standing and facing the back of his laptop, I extended my arm towards Charles whom I recognized from the photo that accompanied his biography on the Guild website. “Sabena, as you know.” 
     “Such a pleasure to meet you, Sabena. Take a seat, don’t be shy.” I sat.
     “So what brings you to the Guild? Besides, of course, being accepted into it?”
     “Well, I’m trying to write,” I took a breath, “I’m trying to write a book,” I cringed as the air left my mouth and congealed as words.
     “Apparently easier done than said,” he laughed.       
     “I got a pretty discouraging response from the last person I told. He didn’t think my life is worthy enough to be written about.”
     “Does his reaction matter, though?”
     “Well, maybe – as a potential reader.”
     “Are you writing this for him?
     “No, but –”
     “Then what is the problem? Writing is difficult enough to do for yourself." My body temperature spiked. I was surprised at his pushing me so early in our relationship, but not angry. While it was just as pointed as my exchanges with colleagues, I valued Charles’s harshness because I saw myself being in his shoes some day, being a “real writer.” The similarity was one I rarely experienced at work. Charles continued. “We do things differently around here. We don’t want to make literature that everyone likes. We want to make literature that is amazing.” He pointed to a framed letter on the wall behind him. “You see that? That was my first rejection letter. It was from a publisher.”
     “Why would you frame that? It feels kind of self-deprecating.”
     “The rejection was for a science fiction novel that I knew was stellar. I could feel it in my gut. Critics can be clowns sometimes.”
     “What are you working on now?” I imagined an eighty-year-old version of myself sitting on his side of the table.
     “A world coming alive as words are written to describe it. Words are the building blocks, after all. I’m building an underwater city, Sub San Francisco.”
     “Clever. How is it coming?”
     He looked down at his keyboard. “This one has been more difficult than previous ones. Over the last several months, it has become difficult for me to focus.” He looked back at me. “Why are we talking about me? You’re the protagonist here. What are your goals? What happens after your piece is published?” I needed a moment before responding. My plan did not bleed past publishing my first book.
     “Just continuing to write I guess. Maybe on a beach somewhere.”
     “Isn’t that what you’re doing right now, without the beach?”
     “It’s hard to focus on writing when I have an unrelated day job. At this point, all I want is to prove to everyone – colleagues, family, friends, and strangers – that I’m capable of producing mature work. Ideally some day I will spend my days writing without being at risk of living on the street.”
     “Sabena, writing does not have to be separate from the rest of your life. No matter where you are, what you are doing, how you feel, you can write.”
     “That sounds unreasonable given my current situation. My job is my life and it’s taking away from my writing.”
     “What is your job?”
     “I work at a large tech company on the business side of things. I guess one day I will be able to run a big company if I want to.”
     “How is your job taking away from your writing? I clearly don’t know the entire situation but perhaps you don’t have the job that’s right for you.”
     “No, I think I’m still getting used to it.”
     “Sabena, do you enjoy your work? Why are you doing it?”
     “I love using what I know about human psychology to create new tech products. It’s an art in itself. Sadly my colleagues don’t value it as much as I do. Unless I have ideas about how we can make more money, they don’t care what I have to say.”
     “And what about writing? Isn’t it your passion?” 
     “I do love writing, but I just don’t think I can support myself as a writer. And, well – ” I hesitated. He nodded for me to continue, “My parents would be so disappointed. I want to have a respectable career.”
     “Do you respect your current job?” Charles asked as he looked at the clock. I was relieved by the implication as there was no easy response to his question. “Goodness, where does the time go? At the risk of sounding too existential, I’m supposed to be telling you why you’re here, why I’m here, and how the Writers Guild will change your life.” I raised a defiant eyebrow. “Or maybe just your Sunday routine. If you really want to write a book, we need to uncover the atman or soul for your writing – the underlying tone that weaves your words together. All you really need is one spark. If it’s real, it will turn into a fire warm enough to cook up an entire book.” His speech was poetic, as is expected of any experienced writer. “I’ll tell you now that it’s going to be a difficult journey. Do you really want to write a book?”
     “I do.” Reconsidering was out of the question. I was already autographing book covers in my mind.
     “Okay. Over the years, I have refined a specific process for successful writing. Are you ready?”
     “I’m your unwritten book.” A creature of routine, the desire to try new things is foreign to me. But I was beginning to see, to my dismay, that I could not write this book without experienced guidance. Writing a book, an act that was supposed to prove my strength, was instead exposing my weaknesses.
     “You and I will meet once a week, though you are welcome here whenever you like. During each of our sessions, I will ask you to write a short piece about some aspect of your life, positive or negative, trivial or profound, significant or negligible. As we go through this exercise, we’ll uncover the fundamental soul that is the premise of your novel. You will then be equipped to craft your novel in its entirety.”
     “Charles, this sounds wonderful, and when you are dealing with someone accomplished, this would make perfect sense.” He opened his mouth to respond but I continued, “You’ll quickly see that my life is not exciting. Every vignette will be insignificant. You need to help me write something exhilarating – controversial, poignant, and intellectual. Like that science fiction novel of yours.” I thought for a moment, “The operating word here is fiction.”
     “Sabena, do you think I went to Mars before writing a book about aliens? All of it, every notion, written or unwritten, comes from right up here,” he said, tapping his forehead. “The world in my mind is nothing but the meaning I find in the world around me.” I wished I could borrow his brain. It was what I needed to complete the book I wanted to write.
     “I just don’t know if this will work – if this will get me where I want to be.”  
     “It will, because our relationship automatically turns you into a writer.”
     “What do you mean?”
     “Think about it. I am going to get to know you through your writing, the same way that most of your readers will. They won’t know you like your friends.”
     “Sure, that’s true.”
     “One of the most important things to remember as a writer is that most of your readers will never meet you in person. Your words need to come to life when a reader sets his eyes on them.”
     “But we just talked about how I shouldn’t worry about pleasing my readers.” He scrunched his nose and nodded.
     “It’s a balancing act. Above all, you should not be writing for anyone but yourself.”     
     “How did you master all these rules? Who was your Charles?”
     “Practice, Sabena. Practice and experience.” Like a child, I wished I could snap once and become a grown up. “Sabena, I want to know more about your job. What makes you so passionate about technology, especially after studying psychology? More passionate than, say, my job sitting and writing all day?”
     “Well –“
     “Uh-uh-uh,” he shook his head as he typed on an imaginary keyboard in the air. “You’re a writer. I’d rather read about your passion than hear about it. This can be the first piece of our writer-reader relationship.” It was an abrupt ending to our conversation, but I was in no place to question Charles’s tactics. I started to type:
 
     Last year, as a part of a company-wide wellness initiative, I needed to complete an on-site blood test. To say blood makes me queasy would be an understatement. After fasting for twelve hours beforehand, I went in for my appointment. A volunteer seated me in a chair across from a nurse who gave me an icy stare.
     She started pressing the veins on my arms and hands. “How much water did you drink this morning?” She may have been asking, but it sounded like scolding. My heart pounded. 
     “Um...I don't know...like a couple water bottles.” She wrinkled her brow.
     “I can’t find your vein. How big was the water bottle?” Without warning she inserted a needle into my hand. Not my arm, but my hand. Shooting pain accompanied. 
     “Oh, you're already starting? I wanted to look away. I can't look at this. I don't know. The bottle was maybe eight or um...” My world started spinning. “I think I'm going to faint,” I told her as I watched blood dribble like molasses from hand to test tube.
     “Stop moving!How much water did you drink today?”     
     “I think I'm going to faint,” I repeated. Frustrated, she pulled the needle out of my hand and looked at me.
     “Do you want to go lie against that wall?” I responded that I needed water. I could feel my body becoming warm; the world was spinning. With a look that said, “Getting you water is not in my job description," the nurse reluctantly departed in search of some. But before doing so, she pawned me off to another nurse: “Go sit in that chair. He'll draw your blood.”
     I moved to the new chair and waited nervously. Finally, it was my turn again.
     “Oh, here's a really good vein.” The nurse pressed firmly on my arm. “Now if you want to look away, I'm going to start.” I looked away. He continued talking. “Did I hear you say you were going to faint before?”  I nodded. “Well I’m not surprised.I tend to have that effect on women.” I managed to smile. “Don’t worry. You’re anxious and uncomfortable. It’s a natural reaction. And there we go, we're done!” I couldn’t believe that the torture was already over – I didn’t realize when it started.
     For weeks after my blood test, I thought about my disparate experiences with the two nurses. The male nurse's compassion, empathy, and sense of humor made him perfect for soothing the discomfort of a needle. And the first nurse's unconcern made her a poor fit. She would be a marvelous prison guard. You can’t plug a person into any occupation and expect success.  
     I am often asked how I keep up in the tech world when I studied psychology. My response is simple: I have always been passionate about technology. When I was choosing a post-graduate job, I knew that as long as I continued to interact with other humans, I would be able to apply my major no matter where I went or what I did. A profound understanding of human psychology -- the ability to connect with others at a deep level, to attribute their behaviors to situations over disposition, and to break down barriers built by cognitive biases -- ensures success in any environment, from drawing blood to building computer software. 
     That first nurse was bad at her job because she lacked fundamental interpersonal skills. She couldn’t connect. While she seemed to have decided on a whim to be a nurse, my choice to join a role in tech was no accident. As our world becomes increasingly powered by technology, our biggest challenge will be to maintain a deep understanding of that technology’s end-users: other humans. No matter the job description. If you ask me, this is why the path from psychology to technology, though unconventional, is completely necessary.
 
     It took me an hour to craft this piece after which I turned my laptop around so the screen was facing Charles, who was working on his own draft. He
looked up and I signaled to my computer. I needed Charles’s assessment of my writing so I could calibrate my idea of “great writing” with his, then figure out how to make my writing “great” in his eyes. In what turned out to be an anticlimactic turn of events, Charles initially refused to look at the piece in my presence.
     “But you forced me to write this."
     “I am not your publisher. It doesn’t matter whether I like it or not. I will read it soon with the hope that it moves me."
     “Please? Just read the first paragraph.” He gave in. I smiled when he scrolled down the page, knowing that he was reading the whole piece. Several moments later, he looked up.

story_txt:
Hi, I'm Ro. I'm writing a novella.
I'm 24 years old and I've been writing for 20 of them. You can check out my most recent work on my blog.

 
My passion for writing about the world around me led me to write a novella which I intend to self-publish on Amazon. The novella is titled Descending the Corporate Ladder. The writing is mostly complete, and it's now time to edit, design a cover, and publish -- that's where I could use a little help from you. 
 
Help me help others write.

As I prepare to self-publish, I need $2500 for final editing, designing a cover, and printing a few physical copies of my book. I'll pay it forward by donating up to $2500 to the SF WritersCorps, an organization dedicated to raising literacy in the Bay Area. Funds after $5000 will go towards additional printing and editing for my book. 
You Get

A book 
The SWEET perk for which you qualify
Warm and fuzzies of helping two people (me and an underprivileged kid or young-adult) achieve their writing dreams

You Give

Improved literacy and creative writing skills to SF youth
A means for this author to launch her novella into the world


What's the book about?
The power of keen determination, the reminder that life can be simultaneously trivial and heavy, and above all, the importance of recognizing your passions. The story follows a colorful free-spirited young professional who, increasingly disillusioned with the world around her and in desperate need of self-validation, decides to write a book. With the help of her cancer-diagnosed writing mentor, she discovers herself by writing about her own experiences with school, work, relationships, family, racism, and gender discrimination.
A candidly introspective, wise, and witty narrative about what it means to be a young twenty-something as it's experienced: the search for a niche, companion, and purpose in life. 
What are early readers saying?
"A timely lesson for our generation, Descending the Corporate Ladder perfectly encapsulates what it means to shave our creative instincts in order to fit the corporate mold and what it takes revisit our innermost ambitions. Highly recommend."
"[Rohini's] ability to reflect upon the confusion of being a 20 some year old today with a little bit of wit brings a sense relief to me. What I liked the most about the novella was that the author's self-reflection provided a forum for me to think through my experiences while reading."


A sneak peek (it's Chapter 6).
     Sunday morning came before I knew it. I awoke out of breath. Snap out of it. They accepted you for a reason. This is embarrassing. After an abridged morning routine I walked to the Wilde House, a Victorian building with fifty regal steps leading up to the front door.     I climbed up the stairs. Five…ten…You can do this…Fifteen…What am I doing here? I should turn around…Fourteen…You’re being a child. Do you want to write a book or not?...Fifteen. I finally made it to the top where the gatekeeper, a mustachioed man wearing a tweed jacket, greeted me at the door. Before he could ask, I spat out the passcode. I was out of place (and not just because I was still standing outside). 
     The gatekeeper nodded and opened the door. Another man, who could have been his identical twin, was waiting on the other side of the door. The men exchanged glances, as if communicating telepathically. The second man stared at me to follow him. Not hearing a single word being spoken, I wondered if people at the Writers Guild relied solely on written communication. I followed him as he took me through a maze of tables. He came to a stop in front of a long rectangular mahogany table. Unprepared to stop so suddenly, I walked into him then hopped backwards. I looked like a klutz.
     Comfortably seated in front of us was an elderly man who could have been my grandfather, dressed in a long sleeve turtleneck, jeans, and sneakers. Sunken cheeks balanced his youthful eyes. His head was almost as shiny as the silver shell of his MacBook. The gatekeeper joined us inside. The first words were spoken. 
     “This is your new protégé, Sabena.” His handlebar mustache twitched as he spoke. “Well, I’ll leave you to it,” he said as he turned and glided away.
     Left standing and facing the back of his laptop, I extended my arm towards Charles whom I recognized from the photo that accompanied his biography on the Guild website. “Sabena, as you know.” 
     “Such a pleasure to meet you, Sabena. Take a seat, don’t be shy.” I sat.
     “So what brings you to the Guild? Besides, of course, being accepted into it?”
     “Well, I’m trying to write,” I took a breath, “I’m trying to write a book,” I cringed as the air left my mouth and congealed as words.
     “Apparently easier done than said,” he laughed.       
     “I got a pretty discouraging response from the last person I told. He didn’t think my life is worthy enough to be written about.”
     “Does his reaction matter, though?”
     “Well, maybe – as a potential reader.”
     “Are you writing this for him?
     “No, but –”
     “Then what is the problem? Writing is difficult enough to do for yourself." My body temperature spiked. I was surprised at his pushing me so early in our relationship, but not angry. While it was just as pointed as my exchanges with colleagues, I valued Charles’s harshness because I saw myself being in his shoes some day, being a “real writer.” The similarity was one I rarely experienced at work. Charles continued. “We do things differently around here. We don’t want to make literature that everyone likes. We want to make literature that is amazing.” He pointed to a framed letter on the wall behind him. “You see that? That was my first rejection letter. It was from a publisher.”
     “Why would you frame that? It feels kind of self-deprecating.”
     “The rejection was for a science fiction novel that I knew was stellar. I could feel it in my gut. Critics can be clowns sometimes.”
     “What are you working on now?” I imagined an eighty-year-old version of myself sitting on his side of the table.
     “A world coming alive as words are written to describe it. Words are the building blocks, after all. I’m building an underwater city, Sub San Francisco.”
     “Clever. How is it coming?”
     He looked down at his keyboard. “This one has been more difficult than previous ones. Over the last several months, it has become difficult for me to focus.” He looked back at me. “Why are we talking about me? You’re the protagonist here. What are your goals? What happens after your piece is published?” I needed a moment before responding. My plan did not bleed past publishing my first book.
     “Just continuing to write I guess. Maybe on a beach somewhere.”
     “Isn’t that what you’re doing right now, without the beach?”
     “It’s hard to focus on writing when I have an unrelated day job. At this point, all I want is to prove to everyone – colleagues, family, friends, and strangers – that I’m capable of producing mature work. Ideally some day I will spend my days writing without being at risk of living on the street.”
     “Sabena, writing does not have to be separate from the rest of your life. No matter where you are, what you are doing, how you feel, you can write.”
     “That sounds unreasonable given my current situation. My job is my life and it’s taking away from my writing.”
     “What is your job?”
     “I work at a large tech company on the business side of things. I guess one day I will be able to run a big company if I want to.”
     “How is your job taking away from your writing? I clearly don’t know the entire situation but perhaps you don’t have the job that’s right for you.”
     “No, I think I’m still getting used to it.”
     “Sabena, do you enjoy your work? Why are you doing it?”
     “I love using what I know about human psychology to create new tech products. It’s an art in itself. Sadly my colleagues don’t value it as much as I do. Unless I have ideas about how we can make more money, they don’t care what I have to say.”
     “And what about writing? Isn’t it your passion?” 
     “I do love writing, but I just don’t think I can support myself as a writer. And, well – ” I hesitated. He nodded for me to continue, “My parents would be so disappointed. I want to have a respectable career.”
     “Do you respect your current job?” Charles asked as he looked at the clock. I was relieved by the implication as there was no easy response to his question. “Goodness, where does the time go? At the risk of sounding too existential, I’m supposed to be telling you why you’re here, why I’m here, and how the Writers Guild will change your life.” I raised a defiant eyebrow. “Or maybe just your Sunday routine. If you really want to write a book, we need to uncover the atman or soul for your writing – the underlying tone that weaves your words together. All you really need is one spark. If it’s real, it will turn into a fire warm enough to cook up an entire book.” His speech was poetic, as is expected of any experienced writer. “I’ll tell you now that it’s going to be a difficult journey. Do you really want to write a book?”
     “I do.” Reconsidering was out of the question. I was already autographing book covers in my mind.
     “Okay. Over the years, I have refined a specific process for successful writing. Are you ready?”
     “I’m your unwritten book.” A creature of routine, the desire to try new things is foreign to me. But I was beginning to see, to my dismay, that I could not write this book without experienced guidance. Writing a book, an act that was supposed to prove my strength, was instead exposing my weaknesses.
     “You and I will meet once a week, though you are welcome here whenever you like. During each of our sessions, I will ask you to write a short piece about some aspect of your life, positive or negative, trivial or profound, significant or negligible. As we go through this exercise, we’ll uncover the fundamental soul that is the premise of your novel. You will then be equipped to craft your novel in its entirety.”
     “Charles, this sounds wonderful, and when you are dealing with someone accomplished, this would make perfect sense.” He opened his mouth to respond but I continued, “You’ll quickly see that my life is not exciting. Every vignette will be insignificant. You need to help me write something exhilarating – controversial, poignant, and intellectual. Like that science fiction novel of yours.” I thought for a moment, “The operating word here is fiction.”
     “Sabena, do you think I went to Mars before writing a book about aliens? All of it, every notion, written or unwritten, comes from right up here,” he said, tapping his forehead. “The world in my mind is nothing but the meaning I find in the world around me.” I wished I could borrow his brain. It was what I needed to complete the book I wanted to write.
     “I just don’t know if this will work – if this will get me where I want to be.”  
     “It will, because our relationship automatically turns you into a writer.”
     “What do you mean?”
     “Think about it. I am going to get to know you through your writing, the same way that most of your readers will. They won’t know you like your friends.”
     “Sure, that’s true.”
     “One of the most important things to remember as a writer is that most of your readers will never meet you in person. Your words need to come to life when a reader sets his eyes on them.”
     “But we just talked about how I shouldn’t worry about pleasing my readers.” He scrunched his nose and nodded.
     “It’s a balancing act. Above all, you should not be writing for anyone but yourself.”     
     “How did you master all these rules? Who was your Charles?”
     “Practice, Sabena. Practice and experience.” Like a child, I wished I could snap once and become a grown up. “Sabena, I want to know more about your job. What makes you so passionate about technology, especially after studying psychology? More passionate than, say, my job sitting and writing all day?”
     “Well –“
     “Uh-uh-uh,” he shook his head as he typed on an imaginary keyboard in the air. “You’re a writer. I’d rather read about your passion than hear about it. This can be the first piece of our writer-reader relationship.” It was an abrupt ending to our conversation, but I was in no place to question Charles’s tactics. I started to type:
 
     Last year, as a part of a company-wide wellness initiative, I needed to complete an on-site blood test. To say blood makes me queasy would be an understatement. After fasting for twelve hours beforehand, I went in for my appointment. A volunteer seated me in a chair across from a nurse who gave me an icy stare.
     She started pressing the veins on my arms and hands. “How much water did you drink this morning?” She may have been asking, but it sounded like scolding. My heart pounded. 
     “Um...I don't know...like a couple water bottles.” She wrinkled her brow.
     “I can’t find your vein. How big was the water bottle?” Without warning she inserted a needle into my hand. Not my arm, but my hand. Shooting pain accompanied. 
     “Oh, you're already starting? I wanted to look away. I can't look at this. I don't know. The bottle was maybe eight or um...” My world started spinning. “I think I'm going to faint,” I told her as I watched blood dribble like molasses from hand to test tube.
     “Stop moving!How much water did you drink today?”     
     “I think I'm going to faint,” I repeated. Frustrated, she pulled the needle out of my hand and looked at me.
     “Do you want to go lie against that wall?” I responded that I needed water. I could feel my body becoming warm; the world was spinning. With a look that said, “Getting you water is not in my job description," the nurse reluctantly departed in search of some. But before doing so, she pawned me off to another nurse: “Go sit in that chair. He'll draw your blood.”
     I moved to the new chair and waited nervously. Finally, it was my turn again.
     “Oh, here's a really good vein.” The nurse pressed firmly on my arm. “Now if you want to look away, I'm going to start.” I looked away. He continued talking. “Did I hear you say you were going to faint before?”  I nodded. “Well I’m not surprised.I tend to have that effect on women.” I managed to smile. “Don’t worry. You’re anxious and uncomfortable. It’s a natural reaction. And there we go, we're done!” I couldn’t believe that the torture was already over – I didn’t realize when it started.
     For weeks after my blood test, I thought about my disparate experiences with the two nurses. The male nurse's compassion, empathy, and sense of humor made him perfect for soothing the discomfort of a needle. And the first nurse's unconcern made her a poor fit. She would be a marvelous prison guard. You can’t plug a person into any occupation and expect success.  
     I am often asked how I keep up in the tech world when I studied psychology. My response is simple: I have always been passionate about technology. When I was choosing a post-graduate job, I knew that as long as I continued to interact with other humans, I would be able to apply my major no matter where I went or what I did. A profound understanding of human psychology -- the ability to connect with others at a deep level, to attribute their behaviors to situations over disposition, and to break down barriers built by cognitive biases -- ensures success in any environment, from drawing blood to building computer software. 
     That first nurse was bad at her job because she lacked fundamental interpersonal skills. She couldn’t connect. While she seemed to have decided on a whim to be a nurse, my choice to join a role in tech was no accident. As our world becomes increasingly powered by technology, our biggest challenge will be to maintain a deep understanding of that technology’s end-users: other humans. No matter the job description. If you ask me, this is why the path from psychology to technology, though unconventional, is completely necessary.
 






     It took me an hour to craft this piece after which I turned my laptop around so the screen was facing Charles, who was working on his own draft. He

looked up and I signaled to my computer. I needed Charles’s assessment of my writing so I could calibrate my idea of “great writing” with his, then figure out how to make my writing “great” in his eyes. In what turned out to be an anticlimactic turn of events, Charles initially refused to look at the piece in my presence.

     “But you forced me to write this."
     “I am not your publisher. It doesn’t matter whether I like it or not. I will read it soon with the hope that it moves me."

     “Please? Just read the first paragraph.” He gave in. I smiled when he scrolled down the page, knowing that he was reading the whole piece. Several moments later, he looked up. 

     “It can be difficult to express your experiences and emotions in a universal manner, but your ability to do so with powerful inward reflection makes you a natural story-teller and a beautiful writer.” I nodded “thank you.” “Of course I wouldn’t be doing my job if I didn’t tell you there is some room for improvement, but this is an extraordinary start.” That validation was all I needed, and I took it as a comfortable place to break for the day.

story:
My name is Twig Deluje' and I'm a writer/publishing consultant living in Santa Fe, New Mexico. Over the last seven years I've been helping folks through their own writing and publishing processes--which means my own writing got placed on the back burner.

Trying to give my own writing a boost, I applied to The LAMBDA Literary Foundation's Writer's Retreat. And got in. With an already extremely competative selection process, and knowing that they had more applicants this year than any of the years prior-- I recieved 1 of only 12 spots in my genre. So yeah...I'm pretty stoked. 

This retreat allows me to be in L.A. for on week of intensive writing, while being mentored by the one and only Samuel Delany while also being surrounded by some of the most amazing and influential emerging voices of our time.

Cost:

Tuition, Room & Board is $1,650, and then I still have to consider travel costs, so that is why I have placed my goal at $2,000.

Please and Thank You:

If you know me, you know I rarely ask for help, esspecially financially, but this is a huge opportunity for me and I know I won't get there withouth the help of my community. I know how hard money is to come by these day, believe you me, and if you can't donate, I understand, but would love your help passing the word along to those who might. Also, if you are uncomfortable donating on line and you are local to the Santa Fe/ABQ area, I am not above working trade for funds. So just message me if you want to negotiate! With Summer in full swing I'm pretty good at labor, cooking, cleaning, growing stuff, and also willing to trade some publishing or editing consultations.

story:
It's 10 days before Christmas when the Postmaster delivers the bad news: There is a Postal Strike at the North Pole - mail carriers all over the world are refusing to deliver children's letters because they are too heavy. They want kids to use email!


Santa falls into a deep sleep and we discover that it is the love contained in the letters that keeps Santa alive. The Elves must find a way to wake Santa and save Christmas, or there will be NO CHRISTMAS PRESENTS THIS YEAR!


This wonderful story has been entertaining families in Hamilton for 10 years as a play and is now available to your family in a wonderful full-colour illustrated hard cover.

Support our Indiegogo campaign today and reserve your copy. 


You can also support our Charity Initiative. Help us donate books to children's hospitals and inner-city kids clubs.

What is the Money for:

The funds will be used to pay our costs to print 5,000 copies of the book - more if we can!

These costs include

  • the illustrations - they take hundreds of hours
  • the printing - hard cover, full colour
  • shipping your perks
  • taxes on everything
  • marketing & promotion
  • indiegogo fee

story:
Hi there! I'm Mindy Kay Smith- the Thoroughly Modern Mommy. And this is a project about teaching women through honesty, humor, and hope that they are not alone. (alliteration intentional.)

My Curriculum Vitae says I'm a performing arts teacher. When I get paid to work, it's generally in that area. But several years ago, after an unsuccessful year of trying to get pregnant, I started to write. I wrote down the story of our journey in trying to conceive (or TTC for those of you visiting from that world. I'm sorry you're in that world, by the way. I hope we can make it a little easier together.) The most tangible result was a now-finished, ready-to-send-to-agents memoir. I'm hoping that one day in the not-so-distant future I can send you the link to buy it on Amazon. But in the meantime...

The other result was realizing I had a love for writing.

ThrlyMdrnMommy.blogspot.com is where I've been developing that love, and my craft.

I've been writing on my blog since my daughter was a few months old. Sometimes it was as close to adult interaction as I could get while we waited for Daddy to come home. I wrote because it helped me.

It turns out that I was also helping others.

I used my blog as an outlet to share my daily struggles and victories as a Mom. I also shared experiences with infertility, mental illness, and adoption.

And it started to get attention.

Over the past month, I've done a few interviews and gotten a few more followers and realized- it's time to make this thing big. I want to reach as many people as I can. I want to let them know they're not alone. And I want them to laugh. With me, at me, whatever.

ThoroughlyModernMommy.com will be different.

There are a million sites out there dealing with infertility, and parenthood, and adoption, and depression. This one will be different in four ways.

1. My blogs address the topics with both sensitivity and humor. I've seen one or the other. Having them together is rare.

2. I'll include resources for people looking for help. Note: I will not be providing this help myself. I am not a doctor. I am not a therapist. I am just a person who unfortunately had to learn a lot about these topics. I will not attempt to give you answers to your personal situation. But I will list straight-forward information. Terms about infertility. Different types of adoptions. Help lines if you're in crisis.

3. This site will NOT include an online community. I know these communities are helpful for many. But I also know that sometimes you just want to know what kind of pregnancy test is best without hearing 27 stories from strangers about the bizarre things that worked for them.

4. When it comes to infertility, adoption, and depression, I am no longer "in it." I will always be a person who suffers from depression, but have been healthy for a long time. I will always hurt from infertility, but am no longer actively trying to conceive. I will be a part of an adoptive family forever, but am no longer going through the process. This is an important difference, because it allows me to focus on telling stories and relaying information.

So, what's the money for?

I want to make ThoroughlyModernMommy.com the fun, inviting site that Moms deserve. This means a great web designer. A talented graphic artist. Marketing campaigns. And equipment that can handle all that. (I'm writing this to you live from my acer aspire one.)

Thank you for taking the time to read all this. I welcome any questions or comments you have about ThoroughlyModernMommy.com

But in the meantime- it's beautiful outside! Go do something fun!

Risks and challenges

I'm a Mom. If you've gotten this far down the page (thank you!) you probably picked that up by now. I'm making arrangements for childcare throughout the month of June so I can work single-mindedly on making this a fun, informative, attractive site. But let's be real. If my daughter needs me- because of illness or sadness or loneliness or whatever-ness, that will come first.

I have a strong track record of successful projects as a teacher and producer in the New York City area, even since becoming a Mom.(I was playing Corie in "Barefoot in the Park" when our daughter arrived. Surprise! But the show went on.) I am confident that I'll be able to produce this project as I have so many others. But is it possible that the timeline will need to be adjusted? Sure.

I will always hurt from infertility, but am no longer actively trying to conceive. I will be a part of an adoptive family forever, but am no longer going through the process. This is an important difference, because it allows me to focus on telling stories and relaying information.
So, what's the money for?
I want to make ThoroughlyModernMommy.com the fun, inviting site that Moms deserve. This means a great web designer. A talented graphic artist. Marketing campaigns. And equipment that can handle all that. (I'm writing this to you live from my acer aspire one.)
Thank you for taking the time to read all this. I welcome any questions or comments you have about ThoroughlyModernMommy.com
But in the meantime- it's beautiful outside! Go do something fun!

Risks and challenges
I'm a Mom. If you've gotten this far down the page (thank you!) you probably picked that up by now. I'm making arrangements for childcare throughout the month of June so I can work single-mindedly on making this a fun, informative, attractive site. But let's be real. If my daughter needs me- because of illness or sadness or loneliness or whatever-ness, that will come first.
I have a strong track record of successful projects as a teacher and producer in the New York City area, even since becoming a Mom.(I was playing Corie in "Barefoot in the Park" when our daughter arrived. Surprise! But the show went on.) I am confident that I'll be able to produce this project as I have so many others. But is it possible that the timeline will need to be adjusted? Sure.

story:
YOU CAN HELP TO PUBLISH "STAVANGER FOR MOTHERS" BY PRE-BOOKING A COPY

From mum 2 writer and publisher

My name is Katalin Galambos, writer and publisher of the book "Oslo for Mothers" and the administrator of the Facebook group called International Mother and Baby Group Oslo (IMOBAGO). My book has been launched in May this year.

On my road to self publishing I met a similarly committed and motivated mum in Stavanger, Cynthia. 

This is how the journey of this book started...

Background

Being a mum is an everyday challenge and even more in a new society with different cultural background.

Cynthia has been living in Stavanger for more than five years with her Norwegian husband. They have since grown to become a family of four - they have a son and a daughter. Both of the kids were born in Stavanger. She started a website for expatriates in Stavanger 4 years ago and that has now evolved to include several Facebook groups specially for foreigners in the Stavanger area, one of which is the Stavanger International Parents group. The group has over 700 members from over 35 countries.

 "Stavanger for Mothers" is relevant to the following groups:

  • pregnant women or families living in Stavanger
  • the ones that are just arriving,
  • and the ones planning to move there

The book's features:                                                   

The book is around 150 pages long and is broken into 9 chapters, each of them with useful, and practical information sorrounded by colourful illustrations. Its size is A5, an optimal size that can easily fit into a hand bag and be always within reach on the go.

Official launch date for the first batch of printed copies is set to be the for the first week of October 2013.

YOU CAN HELP TO PUBLISH "STAVANGER FOR MOTHERS" BY PRE-BOOKING A COPY

In order to be able to give life to the first edition of "Stavanger for Mothers" we need to reach a minimum number of prebooking orders. Every penny is greatly appreciated and will be well used.

It is possible to make contributions already from $1!!!

THANK YOU on behalf of all the international mums living in Stavanger!

story:
1 - L'origine du projet

Bonjour, je suis Julien Larzillière, gérant de l'agence de communication Apresta . Notre équipe travaille sur le projet 1script.fr depuis le début de l'année 2013. Au début, c'était surtout un petit projet "coup de coeur", mais au fil des mois, il a fini par devenir vraiment sérieux.

Aujourd'hui, nous souhaitons mettre des moyens à hauteur de nos ambitions. Nous avons engagé des frais d'avocat, un dépôt de marque, un expert-comptable, une nouvelle banque et un budget détaillé des frais tels que la publicité, l'hébergement.

2 - Notre but

1script.fr a pour but de devenir LA plateforme française de vente et de partage de scripts, tous domaines confondus. Elle va mettre en relation des développeurs / créatifs avec de potentiels acheteurs / agences. Les scripts proposés seront gratuits ou vendus entre 3€ HT et 35€ HT. Les scripts peuvent être de simple fonctions très utiles ou de véritables applications.

Nous n'avons pas de concurrent direct en France, ce qui laisse une belle place pour notre projet. Nous visons une somme de 10.000 € pour débuter ce projet. Bien sûr, cette somme n'a pas été choisie au hasard, elle entre dans un prévisionnel établi par un comptable.

3 - État du projet

A ce jour, 60% du site est en place, un accès aux bêta testeurs est en place. Il nous reste à terminer le site, payer les différents intervenants, préparer la campagne publicitaire, pré-remplir le site et Let's go !

4 - Liens utiles

·  Le site, réservé aux testeurs à ce jour : http://www.1script.fr/
·  Notre page Facebook : https://www.facebook.com/1script.fr
·  Notre compte Twitter : https://twitter.com/1scriptfr
·  La vidéo qui explique tout : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CI0CuoSYqFk
·  Le communiqué de presse : http://1script.fr/1script-communique_de_presse.pdf

story:
Hi! We are Alyson Herzig and Jessica Azar...Two crazy, blogging humorists on a serious pursuit to create a book that will help individuals that are enduring the pains of mental illness. We both have found that although our illnesses have dark and difficult moments that laughter really is one of our best medicines. 

Let us tell you more  about ourselves and our awesome project!

Alyson's blog, TheShitastrophy.com, has had over 180K views in less than a year. She wrote a post:The Moment the Panic Began that detailed the instant and circumstances that surrounded the moment she developed panic attacks. These attacks have plagued her for the last 13 years. After sharing her story she received an amazing outpouring of support from friends, family, fans, and other bloggers. It really has been quite humbling.

Jessica blogs at Herd Management and has often written about her experiences in living with Bipolar Disorder. She has had many readers reach out to her for support through social media after reading her posts.  

We both connected online and discussed our personal experiences, the stigma of having a mental illness, and how we cope. We both personally know of other writers who also suffer and blog about their illnesses and realized that although we all have a dark side, we also all have a very funny and light side. We connected the dots and recognized that humor is the counter balance to many of our own and our fellow writers mental illnesses.

It was through this realization that the idea was born to create an Anthology of humorists that provide a glimpse into their specific disorder, but balanced with a very funny story. We have already reached out to fellow writers and have received commitments to provide both a funny and serious look at their lives.  We seek to remove the stigma associated with Mental Illness by showing that there are many successful people laughing their way through the rougher days. Our hope is to help educate  the public on the illnesses and experiences associated with them.

We are requesting the funds of $4,500 to pay for a professional editor, the cost for the cover design, a copy editor, and a printer. None of this money will be used to to pay either Jessica or Alyson. It is our plan to pay our authors from our own pockets and then a portion of the royalties at a later time. 

We believe strongly in this project and know that it would help many people that often feel alone when struggling with mental illness, as we did when we were first diagnosed. Humor is so important in keeping the human spirit alive and thriving, and in publishing this book we hope to encourage those struggling to keep laughing. 

It is our hope that you will donate in honor or memory of those you know and love that suffer from mental illness. It will mean the world to us and those who our Anthology impacts....You could help change someones outlook on their situation by showing them that they're in good company.

We will also be requesting all authors to select a local charitable fund that helps forward the education of Mental Illness to donate a portion of their royalties too. We will highlight that organization in our book as well. 

If you are unable to contribute, we would be very excited if you choose to share our campaign and story through the IndieGoGo share tools that are available!!! Help us spread the word all over the world through Social Media!

story:
Short Summary

Let me introduce myself, my name is Paul Clarkson, for the past 2 years I have been running the Facebook page 'Full Independence for Scotland'. https://www.facebook.com/pages/Full-Independence-for-Scotland/307256019306036?ref=hl 

 I also tweet about the referendum (among other things) on Twitter @Clarkson77 https://twitter.com/Clarkson77

 Recently I have become concerned that many of the working Class people of Scotland remain uninformed, or worse, disconnected from the main debate surrounding the biggest decision the people of Scotland are likely to make in our lifetime, the Independence referendum on 18th September 2014.

 Anyway, long story short, I've decided to make an attempt at starting a campaign group to take the Yes campaign message of hope directly to the working class communities of Scotland.

 I've also created 'Working Class Yes' on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/pages/Working-Class-Yes/464554260339525?ref=hl as a means of sharing the progress of the group on social media.


What We Need & What You Get

Funding will be used for campaign materials, for example Yes badges, flyers, street stalls etc.


The Impact

The main impact will be the ability to bypass the misinformation of the mainstream media by taking the message of hope for a better Scotland directly to the people who will benefit most from a fairer society.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cant contribute financially, please help by sharing this campaign with your friends on social media. Thank you.

story:
What is CJFE?

Canadian Journalists for Free Expression (CJFE) is a Canadian organization that works to defend and protect the right to free expression in Canada and around the world.

CJFE monitors, defends and reports on free expression and access to information in Canada and abroad. Rooted in the field of journalism, we promote a free media as essential to a fair and open society. CJFE boldly champions the free expression rights of all people, and encourages and supports individuals and groups in the protection of their own and others' free expression rights.

Visit our website to learn more about our work to protect free expression in Canada and abroad. 

What is the Review?

Every year on World Press Freedom Day (May 3), we publish our Review of Free Expression in Canada. It is the ONLY publication of its kind in Canada that:

  • Provides a report card grading free expression in Canada.
  • Holds government, institutions, businesses, and society as a whole responsible for their impact on freedom of expression in Canada.
  • Looks at the nation’s most pressing issues of free expression in the past year.
  • Analyzes the results of major court cases.
  • Examines trends, breakthroughs and obstacles.

This past year has been significant and challenging for free expression in Canada. From the Snowden leaks to the TPP negotiations, Bill C-461 to the silencing of Canadian scientists, and with countless attacks on journalists and protesters around the world, publications like our annual Review are needed now, more than ever.

Over the past five years, the media has been able to make Canadians aware of how much their access to information, their right to be informed on issues of major importance, has been eroded. But this is just the tip of the iceberg, as governments and the private sector withhold the kind of information that we all need to make informed decisions. CJFE is the only organization in Canada that consistently holds those in authority accountable by drawing public attention to the determined efforts to withhold information.

This year, we are on a mission to make the Review better than ever before. We want to report on more efforts to suppress what should be public information, we want to reach a broader audience, and strengthen CJFE so that we can contribute to a more transparent political and business environment.

Click on the links below to view previous issues of the Review:

  • 2009/2010
  • 2010/2011
  • 2011/2012
  • 2012/2013

Why we need your help

It takes 43 staff and volunteers more than 2600 hours to create the Review of Free Expression in Canada. 

Your support will help us: 

  • Distribute the Review of Free Expression in Canada FREE to journalism and communication programs at universities and colleges across the country.
  • Engage with policymakers to develop measures that will make information more accessible and protect whistleblowers.
  • Undergo further research on the critical issues addressed in the Review.
  • Pay for the production of the Review, including research, writing, layout and printing.

3 reasons to get involved

  1. Free expression matters. If we take this fundamental right for granted, it will erode. CJFE’s job is to monitor the state of free expression in Canada and communicate to Canadians the progress or roadblocks to reporting on issues of importance to us all. We take the position that what you don’t know CAN hurt you. 
  2. We need to spread the word. The Review is a key tool in measuring our right to free expression in Canada and we need your help to make sure it reaches as many people as possible.
  3. We know what we’re doing. Our experience, energy, and expertise results in a unique and accessible product that educates and informs Canadians. 

How can you help?

  1. Donate. The Review engages Canadians on critical issues and informs them about how their right to free expression is faring in this country – this is your chance to make sure that happens. It is a big job, and every dollar goes a long way.
  2. Share. Crowdfunding isn’t based on large donations, but a LOT of donations. Every person you pass this on to is one more person who knows about their right to free expression, CJFE’s work, and the importance of holding those in authority accountable. Tweet #CJFEreview along with this link to our campaign to rally more support for free expression: http://bit.ly/1c1QPWA

story:
I'm Hazel West, a self-published author of five novels including A Case of Poisons which is the novel of interest here. I'm also the author of On a Foreign Field which is 5 star rated on Amazon and Goodreads and By Blood or By Bond my last published novel about Roman Britain.

What is A Case of Poisons  about?

Anthony Maxwell is a private investigator, a consultant for the mostly incompetent inspectors at Scotland Yard, on occasion a writer, and always a lover of coffee. He has been working small cases for several years to pay the bills when he’s introduced to the first multiple murder case of his career early one morning, when a witness catches a man trying to unload a body to bury in a nearby graveyard. Soon the first body is joined by three more in the course of a single morning and Anthony knows this is no ordinary serial murder case. And why is the murderer targeting beggars and urchin children? If that wasn’t cause enough to worry, all the victims are covered with horrible wounds and show signs of exotic poisoning. Anthony, along with his partners Tobias—an ex-broadsman and well-know charmer—and Scamp—a street smart and talented young woman—work to find out who is murdering the helpless beggars and children in such horrifying ways. The first book in this new Victorian steampunk series takes the three companions to the limits of their abilities as they go up against canny murderers, bruisers who appear invincible, anarchist groups, and even ancient British royalty in the biggest case Anthony Maxwell has ever worked in his career.

 

This campaign is to help fun the production and promotion of my newest book, the first in a Victorian steampunk mystery series chronicling the adventurous cases of my private detective Anthony Maxwell. It's an action-packed series, narrated by the witty and gentlemanly Anthony and is kind of a cross between Sherlock Holmes and The Three Musketeers with a steampunk flair added. What I'm raising money for is mostly promotional: I want to do a long blog tour to get the series out to potential readers, and other promotional things like giveaways and advertisement. Every time I publish a book, I try to do a little more to get it out, and being a self-published author is hard because I have to do all promotion myself, finding blog spots and paying for advertisement out of pocket. I'm not going to lie, indie authors are almost always starving artists, at least until we can sell enough books to make up the difference of how much we pay to produce them. What I really want at the end of the day, is for people to enjoy my books, but in order for them to be able to find them, promotional steps need to be taken so a wider audience of people will have the chance to read them.

In short, I can't do what I want without YOUR help! Even if you pledge $5, that's a huge help toward my goal. In today's social media, it's so easy to spread the word without costing people much, if anything at all. 

I'm hoping to raise $800 (and in that is the cost of all perks you will receive if you donate as well!) But even if I don't make that amount, every little bit will help. This is a breakdown of where the money will go:

A long virtual book tour

Buying copies for giveaways

Printing costs for bookmarks and posters for promotion and giveaways

Advertisement 

A domain for an official author website

If I end up having more money than what I planned for, everything that is left will go toward the production of the next novel I publish, so in reality, all this money will provide something for fans and potential readers even more than me. I'm looking forward to the satisfaction of people enjoying my book. Anthony Maxwell is a character I fell in love with, and everyone who has read him so far (and not just family members, mind!) have also loved him, so I'm really excited about the start of this series. To begin with, it's my first series, and on top of that, I think it's the kind of book everyone will enjoy. There's something in it for readers of all ages.

Extra money might also go to coffee if I get really desperate-can't write without that.

 

Now for the perks (I know this is the part you've all been waiting for)

I've got some fun thank you gifts for people who contribute. Here's a breakdown of what you'll receive for helping out:

$5- a signed bookmark

$10- an ebook copy of A Case of Poisons in your choice of format

$25- a signed paperback copy of A Case of Poisons and a bookmark

$50- signed paperback, ebook, and a signed poster with the cover art

$75- a signed paperback, ebook, poster, and (here's the exciting part) you get to name a character for the next book

$100- a signed paperback, a lovely pocket watch (http://www.gentlemansemporium.com/store/003895.php) and naming a character for the next book.

story_txt:
I'm Hazel West, a self-published author of five novels including A Case of Poisons which is the novel of interest here. I'm also the author of On a Foreign Field which is 5 star rated on Amazon and Goodreads and By Blood or By Bond my last published novel about Roman Britain.
What is A Case of Poisons  about?
Anthony Maxwell is a private investigator, a consultant for the mostly incompetent inspectors at Scotland Yard, on occasion a writer, and always a lover of coffee. He has been working small cases for several years to pay the bills when he’s introduced to the first multiple murder case of his career early one morning, when a witness catches a man trying to unload a body to bury in a nearby graveyard. Soon the first body is joined by three more in the course of a single morning and Anthony knows this is no ordinary serial murder case. And why is the murderer targeting beggars and urchin children? If that wasn’t cause enough to worry, all the victims are covered with horrible wounds and show signs of exotic poisoning. Anthony, along with his partners Tobias—an ex-broadsman and well-know charmer—and Scamp—a street smart and talented young woman—work to find out who is murdering the helpless beggars and children in such horrifying ways. The first book in this new Victorian steampunk series takes the three companions to the limits of their abilities as they go up against canny murderers, bruisers who appear invincible, anarchist groups, and even ancient British royalty in the biggest case Anthony Maxwell has ever worked in his career.
 
This campaign is to help fun the production and promotion of my newest book, the first in a Victorian steampunk mystery series chronicling the adventurous cases of my private detective Anthony Maxwell. It's an action-packed series, narrated by the witty and gentlemanly Anthony and is kind of a cross between Sherlock Holmes and The Three Musketeers with a steampunk flair added. What I'm raising money for is mostly promotional: I want to do a long blog tour to get the series out to potential readers, and other promotional things like giveaways and advertisement. Every time I publish a book, I try to do a little more to get it out, and being a self-published author is hard because I have to do all promotion myself, finding blog spots and paying for advertisement out of pocket. I'm not going to lie, indie authors are almost always starving artists, at least until we can sell enough books to make up the difference of how much we pay to produce them. What I really want at the end of the day, is for people to enjoy my books, but in order for them to be able to find them, promotional steps need to be taken so a wider audience of people will have the chance to read them.
In short, I can't do what I want without YOUR help! Even if you pledge $5, that's a huge help toward my goal. In today's social media, it's so easy to spread the word without costing people much, if anything at all.

A long virtual book tour
Buying copies for giveaways
Printing costs for bookmarks and posters for promotion and giveaways
Advertisement 
A domain for an official author website
If I end up having more money than what I planned for, everything that is left will go toward the production of the next novel I publish, so in reality, all this money will provide something for fans and potential readers even more than me. story:
THE EASTERN ROMAN EMPIRE

The Eastern Roman Empire, also known by modern historians as the Byzantine Empire, was a part of the Roman Empire that survived after it's Western territories fell in the 300-400's from constant barbarian invasions.  The Eastern Empire continued as the Roman Empire, keeping in many of the original traditions as well as throwing in new ones.  

What we seek to do is to purchase land around the Mediterranean Sea and use these as a staging point from which the Empire can slowly restore Roman territory.    The money raised will go to six things;

  • Creating and training a small force of armed soldiers to help defend the empire from external and internal threats
  • Purchasing and securing land that the Empire will use as a home-base to expand itself or gain influence.
  • Constructing infrastructure that is needed to run a technological civilization (This is a requirement for all nations in this era)
  • Founding and funding the various governmental organizations.
  • Transport supplies and other personnel to the land that we will use for expanding our glorious Empire.  
  • Constructing a stable economy that can take part in the global market.

All the money will be well-spent on slowly reconstructing the Empire, and we seek to admit our Empire to the United Nations.  

#OccupyAnatolia

#OccupyConstantinople

In the case that we fail to prove ourselves worthy of the position of Emperor, we will refund all the money or donate it to a charity of your choice.  None of the funds will be cashed out until we are sure we can make an attempt to reestablish ourselves.  


WHAT IF WE AREN'T FULLY FUNDED

Less than $1,500,000 raised - Rome is having a very bad day and cannot into political relevance.  Project is abandoned and all funds returned to their owners.
$1,500,000 to $15,000,000 raised - Rome is having a bad day but can purchase one or two small islands in the Mediterranean.  Money for infrastructure will be funded out of the surplus amount, paid for by own money, or raised individually through another campaign.
$15,000,000 to $60,000,000 raised - Rome is having a rather crappy, but tolerable day and can purchase some land in the Mediterranean region with small amounts of infrastructure to set up economy and government.
$60,000,000 to $150,000,000 raised - Rome is having a moderate day and can make do with the funds by purchasing land and islands in the Mediterranean region, constructing some government buildings, buying infrastructure, 
$150,000,000 to $250,000,000 raised - Rome is having a good day and can set up local economy and foreign relations from the start, construct a small capitol and necessary infrastructure, set up electricity and solar farms, and build a small defense force.
$250,000,000 and above - Rome has just won the lottery.  The Empire will purchase tons of land, construct infrastructure powered by solar farms and renewable energy, build a small military, and set up government, economy, and foreign relations.
